Context: After monoassociation, EcN was detected in spleens and livers of TLR4−/− and CD14−/− but not wildtype mice.
In contrast to wildtype (WT) mice, EcN monoassociation resulted in increased bacterial invasion in TLR4−/− mice to liver and spleen 3 days after inoculation (Fig. 1a).

In animal models of experimental colitis Cd14 has been identified as a promising candidate gene21, which plays a protective role in experimental IBD18,22.
Therefore, in the present study EcN monoassociation was utilized in a CD14−/− mouse model to reveal alterations of the intestinal mucosa and the influence of CD14 on the intestinal homeostasis.
Thus, increased cell death and reduced EJ expression point towards epithelial barrier impairment in this model.
Together these findings indicate the importance of the hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic cell compartment to reduce bacterial invasion and maintain the intestinal barrier in this model.

Values are shown as fold induction (n = 5). www.nature.com/scientificreports/ 7Scientific RepoRts | (2018) 8:719 | DOI:10.1038/s41598-017-19062-7 The level of EcN colonization was comparable among these two models (Supplementary Fig. 1d).
Activation of the TLR2 pathway has been shown to strengthen the intestinal barrier by enhancing the TJ formation41,42, e.g. in a Citrobacter rodentium-induced colitis model43.
Neither the hematopoietic nor the non-hematopoietic cell compartment could completely prevent bacterial translocation in this model.
Therefore, B cell function was further assessed in this model.
To provide evidence regarding the protective role of B cells in this model, the CD20 antibody was utilized to deplete B cells in WT mice.

Additionally, WT recipients of CD14−/− BM did not show dysregulated EJ expression, strengthening the hypothesis of a CD14-dependent communication pathway between B cells and epithelial cells, likely involving the soluble form. www.nature.com/scientificreports/ 1 0Scientific RepoRts | (2018) 8:719 | DOI:10.1038/s41598-017-19062-7 To further support the role of B cells in this model, GF CXCR5−/− and CCR7−/− mice were colonized with EcN.
It is intriguing to speculate that innate-like immune cells (B-1 and marginal zone B cells) contribute to the maintenance of the intestinal homeostasis in this model.
